review.title: RDF Translator: A RESTful Multi-Format Data Converter for the Semantic Web
review.abstract: The interdisciplinary nature of the Semantic Web and the many projects put forward by the community led to a large number of widely accepted serialization formats for RDF. Most of these RDF syntaxes have been developed out of a necessity to serve specific purposes better than existing ones, e.g. RDFa was proposed as an extension to HTML for embedding non-intrusive RDF statements in human-readable documents. Nonetheless, the RDF serialization formats are generally transducible among themselves given that they are commonly based on the RDF model. In this paper, we present (1) a RESTful Web service based on the HTTP protocol that translates between different serializations. In addition to its core functionality, our proposed solution provides (2) features to accommodate frequent needs of Semantic Web developers, namely a straightforward user interface with copy-to-clipboard functionality, syntax highlighting, persistent URI links for easy sharing, cool URI patterns, and content negotiation using respective HTTP headers. We demonstrate the benefit of our converter by presenting two use cases.

sections.heading: 3 RDF Translator
sections.text: In this section, we introduce RDF Translator18, a web service for bidirectional conversion between different RDF data formats, namely RDFa, Microdata, RDF / XML, Notation 3, N-Triples, RDF / JSON and JSON-LD. Unlike most of the tools presented in Section 2, our online converter is a comprehensive and convenient web service with semantic web developers in mind. We then outline the service architecture, followed by describing the user interface and the features available to ensure the ease of development of our web service. This is then complemented by specifying the underlying REST API and the associated adherence to best practices in web technology design, i.e. cool URIs, content negotiation and CORS support.

sections.heading: 3.1 Service Architecture
sections.text: Fig. 1 shows the architecture of the RDF Translator. The REST API supports both HTTP GET and HTTP POST request methods, the latter being more suitable for submitting raw data for conversion by the service. For human users, the web service offers an intuitive web user interface that offers two options, namely the provision of a web resource URI to convert content or raw textual input for translation into a target format.

sections.heading: 3.4 Cross-Origin Resource Sharing Support
sections.text: This website dynamics is enabled by JavaScript and its XMLHTTPRequest object to retrieve data under a specific URL, and is supported by almost every modern web browser. However, in web browsers there are security restrictions (the "same policy of origin" 24) that prevent JavaScript applications from loading content from external resources that are not under the control of the website. Cross-country resource sharing [7] solves the problem of the same policy of origin by adding an HTTP reply header to allow open access across domain boundaries. The header looks like this and is included in the reply header of every answer returned by our REST API: Access -Control -Allow -Origin: *.

sections.heading: 3.5 Vocabulary Detection
sections.text: RDFLib, the RDF library on which our service relies, already defines a significant number of namespace prefixes of popular vocabulary. They are used to add commonly accepted namespace prefix declarations to syntaxes such as notation 3. Unfortunately, prefix declarations of certain or newly created vocabulary are not to be found in this seed list. However, to provide meaningful prefixes for unknown vocabularies, our service integrates the Prefix.cc25 lookup service as a fallback solution, using the service's reverse lookup function to obtain the appropriate namespace prefix. Specifically, the service first checks whether a vocabulary is already in the list of vocabularies known to RDFLib. If not, it claims that the prefix of the vocabulary URI from prefix.cc. sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper we presented the RDF Translator, a RESTful web service that comes with a developer-friendly user interface and a REST API. The web service is intended as a comprehensive solution for translation between the most popular serialization formats currently available on the Semantic Web. Our proposal focuses not only on the technical aspects of supporting the development of popular RDF data formats with syntax transformability, but also on collaborative aspects of the development process. What makes our solution unique among the web services presented in Section 2 is the combination of features such as the bi-directional conversion capability of a number of popular RDF data formats, the possibility of syntax highlighting for all supported serialization formats, linking functionalities for better collaboration, a clean and 27 http: / / www.stalsoft.com / gromestraightforward web user interface with active user support, and adherence to innovative web technologies from Web latenables us to update the Web libraries that are frequently available to our libraries, the 11DF libraries.
